unnormalised: ### My Health Journey: Numbers, Tests, and the Long Road Back
normalised: My Health Journey: Numbers, Tests, and the Long Road Back

unnormalised: It all started subtly, with a persistent cough and a nagging fatigue I couldn’t shake off. I brushed it aside, attributing it to the Delhi pollution, the stress of work, and the general hustle of everyday life. After all, 12-hour workdays were the norm, and I wasn't exactly prioritizing my well-being. It took my wife, Priya, noticing I was losing weight – I’d dropped from 75 kg to roughly 68 kg in what felt like a blink – for me to finally take it seriously.
normalised: It all started subtly, with a persistent cough and a nagging fatigue I couldn’t shake off. I brushed it aside, attributing it to the Delhi pollution, the stress of work, and the general hustle of everyday life. After all, twelve hour workdays were the norm, and I wasn't exactly prioritizing my well-being. It took my wife, Priya, noticing I was losing weight – I’d dropped from seventy five kilogram to roughly sixty eight kilogram in what felt like a blink – for me to finally take it seriously.

unnormalised: My first visit was to Dr. Sharma, a general physician near our home in Dwarka. He listened patiently, took my vitals (BP: 130/85, Temp: 99°F), and ordered a battery of tests. The lab requisition form felt like a daunting list of unknowns: CBC, ESR, LFT, KFT, TSH. The prospect of understanding what they all meant was overwhelming.
normalised: My first visit was to Doctor Sharma, a general physician near our home in Dwarka. He listened patiently, took my vitals (B P: one hundred and thirty divided by eighty five, Temp: ninety nine degree fahrenheit), and ordered a battery of tests. The lab requisition form felt like a daunting list of unknowns: C-B-C, E-S-R, L-F-T, K-F-T, T-S-H. The prospect of understanding what they all meant was overwhelming.

unnormalised: The blood test report arrived two days later. My hemoglobin was low at 11.5 g/dL. My erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was alarmingly high, hitting 45 mm/hr. And the lymphocytes were registering at a hefty 45%, hinting at possible inflammation. I frantically googled each value. Bad idea. I convinced myself I had something truly awful. Priya, bless her heart, calmed me down and booked an appointment with a specialist.
normalised: The blood test report arrived two days later. My hemoglobin was low at eleven point five gram per d-L. My erythrocyte sedimentation rate (E-S-R) was alarmingly high, hitting forty five millimeter per hour. And the lymphocytes were registering at a hefty forty five percent, hinting at possible inflammation. I frantically googled each value. Bad idea. I convinced myself I had something truly awful. Priya, bless her heart, calmed me down and booked an appointment with a specialist.

unnormalised: Dr. Kapoor, a pulmonologist at Max Hospital, reviewed the reports and ordered a chest X-ray. The X-ray revealed a shadow in my left lung. A CT scan followed, confirming the presence of a mass. My world felt like it was crumbling. He mentioned staging, survival rates, and terms like "biopsy" and "chemotherapy." A whirlwind of anxiety descended. I couldn't sleep. I lost my appetite, even though Priya made my favorite Palak Paneer. I'm grateful that she suggested I join a support group for cancer patients.

unnormalised: The biopsy was scheduled for 05/07/2023. Those few days were the longest of my life. Finally, the results came back. Lung cancer, Stage IIB. The numbers stared back at me from the pathology report, a stark reality. The treatment plan involved surgery followed by chemotherapy.
normalised: The biopsy was scheduled for fifth july two thousand and twenty three. Those few days were the longest of my life. Finally, the results came back. Lung cancer, Stage two B. The numbers stared back at me from the pathology report, a stark reality. The treatment plan involved surgery followed by chemotherapy.

unnormalised: Surgery was scheduled for 25/07/2023. Before the operation, my surgeon gave me some stats: Approximately 60% chance of survival with the surgery, and 30-40% survival rate after 5 years. I took those numbers as my goal. I needed to be in that percentage.
normalised: Surgery was scheduled for twenty fifth july two thousand and twenty three. Before the operation, my surgeon gave me some stats: Approximately sixty percent chance of survival with the surgery, and thirty to forty percent survival rate after five years. I took those numbers as my goal. I needed to be in that percentage.

unnormalised: The chemotherapy was a brutal ordeal, spread across 6 cycles, each lasting 21 days. Nausea, fatigue, hair loss – it was everything I had read about, and more. I lost another 5 kg during the treatment. However, the PET scan after the 4th cycle showed a significant reduction in the size of the tumor. The oncologist said there had been an approximately 70% reduction in tumour size.
normalised: The chemotherapy was a brutal ordeal, spread across six cycles, each lasting twenty one days. Nausea, fatigue, hair loss – it was everything I had read about, and more. I lost another five kilogram during the treatment. However, the P-E-T scan after the fourth cycle showed a significant reduction in the size of the tumor. The oncologist said there had been an approximately seventy percent reduction in tumour size.

unnormalised: Recovery has been slow but steady. My energy levels are gradually returning. Priya makes sure I eat nutritious food. It's been a long journey filled with numbers – test results, percentages, dates, weights. But these numbers, while initially terrifying, helped me understand my health. My next check up with Dr. Kapoor is on 15/01/2025, and I'm hoping for good news. I'm also looking forward to my next visit with the support group. This experience has taught me the importance of early detection, listening to your body, and the unwavering support of loved ones. Numbers can be scary, but they can also be a roadmap to recovery.
